thread.title: Auburn cornerbacks want to be the country's next best duo
thread.title_full: Auburn cornerbacks want to be the country's next best duo

title: Auburn cornerbacks want to be the country's next best duo
text:
Slot to Auburn Links 
AUBURN, Ala. — Javaris Davis and Carlton Davis want everyone in the SEC and the country to be talking about them next season. 
Auburn’s starting cornerbacks have worked their way up the depth chart over the last two years ( Carlton Davis started as a freshman), and are poised to excel starting on opposite sides of the field in the fall. 
“Oh my God, Javaris is — he’s like climbed the mountain,” Carlton Davis said. “Freshman year he redshirted, then last year was his coming-out year and I’m expecting an even bigger year this year for him. We just go to work every day, push each other, make plays and just be that SEC duo. That’s really what we’re looking for: just being that SEC duo that everyone talks about — that Quincy Wilson and Jalen Tabor type. That’s what we’re working toward this year.” 
Wilson and Tabor were stars at Florida, where they both decided to jump into the NFL Draft following their junior seasons. Some prognosticators believe they both could be selected in the first round later this spring. 
The Davis duo have a ways to go before receiving those accolades. 
Carlton Davis had 46 tackles and 10 pass breakups last season, but did not record an interception. Javaris Davis picked off two passes and broke up seven throws. 
“I just have to keep going,” Javaris Davis said. “Never take a play off. (Play) every play like it’s my last, and that’s what coach always preached to us. So, I just have to stay on top of it and play every play like it’s my last play.” 
Carlton Davis was an All-SEC selection as a freshman. The rising junior knows bigger things could be on the horizon for himself and his teammate in the fall. 
“We’re veterans now,” Carlton Davis said. “It’s time to really get after it. We’re really trying to help our receivers grow more, because we’ve got a lot of young receivers, but we’re experienced guys. We’ve been there, done that. This is our second spring, so by now we’ve seen a lot. We’re just trying to help our teammates grow.” 
Javaris Davis’ strength is in man-to-man press coverages, Carlton Davis said. “His speed is outrageous and he has good ball skills, so he’s going to make plays on the ball,” he explained.
